talk.author: did:plc:ieipici6is42y7e6r2cvk4x2
talk.utter:
"None of these are Gen AI systems trained on user content."

That can be read in quite a weasely way. Are the classifiers or recommendation systems built using models pretrained with data obtained without consent?

talk.author: did:plc:gg7eowb5bhs32coftdxnq2if
talk.utter: Training on Shakespeare is training without consent

talk.author: did:plc:ieipici6is42y7e6r2cvk4x2
talk.utter: Quite so (and I say that as someone who’s done that). Here’s a more interesting one: training on Agatha Christie. We really need to work out where our boundaries lie here.

talk.author: did:plc:ieipici6is42y7e6r2cvk4x2
talk.utter: Here’s one you might like (but others here will find sketchy): I wanted to try style transfer of Mary Shelley. Obviously, the most important text is Frankenstein. But Frankenstein was edited by Percy, so I bought a copy with the reconstructed attempt at the original text. It holds a new copyright…

talk.author: did:plc:gg7eowb5bhs32coftdxnq2if
talk.utter:
It can be sketchy and interesting and more all at the same time. How would you judge if it had worked? And yeah the cutoff question - how much time needs to pass?

Do you think copyright rules likely to change much in light of all this?

talk.author: did:plc:ieipici6is42y7e6r2cvk4x2
talk.utter:
There has to be some clarification of fair use, one way or another.

I was listening, when you replied earlier, to the new Spotify full-cast dramatisation of 'The Mysterious at Styles' produced "with the permission of Agatha Christie ltd."
